title: Part A
stimulusHtml:
Part (a)—4 points

Students were awarded 1 point for each of two factors identified. Students were also awarded 1 point each for explaining how these two factors contribute to declining voter turnout. Some acceptable contributing factors include less party mobilization, a larger electorate, a more mobile population, de-alignment, cynicism, apathy, and the loss of a sense of efficacy.
descriptions: The student response failed to identify and explain how voter turnout in federal elections has declined.

The student response earned one of the following points:

  • 1 point for EACH of two factors identified.

  • 1 point for EACH explanation on how these two factors contribute to declining voter turnout.

Some acceptable contributing factors include less party mobilization, a larger electorate, a more mobile population, de-alignment, cynicism, apathy, and the loss of a sense of efficacy.

The student response earned two of the following points:

  • 1 point for EACH of two factors identified.

  • 1 point for EACH explanation on how these two factors contribute to declining voter turnout.

Some acceptable contributing factors include less party mobilization, a larger electorate, a more mobile population, de-alignment, cynicism, apathy, and the loss of a sense of efficacy.

The student response earned three of the following points:

  • 1 point for EACH of two factors identified.

  • 1 point for EACH explanation on how these two factors contribute to declining voter turnout.

Some acceptable contributing factors include less party mobilization, a larger electorate, a more mobile population, de-alignment, cynicism, apathy, and the loss of a sense of efficacy.

The student response earned four of the following points:

  • 1 point for EACH of two factors identified.

  • 1 point for EACH explanation on how these two factors contribute to declining voter turnout.

Some acceptable contributing factors include less party mobilization, a larger electorate, a more mobile population, de-alignment, cynicism, apathy, and the loss of a sense of efficacy.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml:
Part (b)—4 points

Students were awarded 1 point for each of two reasons identified. Students were also awarded 1 point each for explaining why these two reasons could plausibly account for differences in voter turnout in presidential and mid­term elections. Some acceptable reasons include greater information available about presidential candidates and issues, greater media interest in presidential elections, greater spending on presidential elections, and the perception of the greater importance of presidential elections.
descriptions: The student failed to identify and explain any reasons why voter turnout has been higher in presidential elections than in midterm elections.

The student response earn one of the following points:

  • 1 point for each of two reasons identified.

  • 1 point each for explaining why these two reasons could plausibly account for differences in voter turnout in presidential and mid­term elections.

Some acceptable reasons include greater information available about presidential candidates and issues, greater media interest in presidential elections, greater spending on presidential elections, and the perception of the greater importance of presidential elections

The student response earn two of the following points:

  • 1 point for each of two reasons identified.

  • 1 point each for explaining why these two reasons could plausibly account for differences in voter turnout in presidential and mid­term elections.

Some acceptable reasons include greater information available about presidential candidates and issues, greater media interest in presidential elections, greater spending on presidential elections, and the perception of the greater importance of presidential elections

The student response earn three of the following points:

  • 1 point for each of two reasons identified.

  • 1 point each for explaining why these two reasons could plausibly account for differences in voter turnout in presidential and mid­term elections.

Some acceptable reasons include greater information available about presidential candidates and issues, greater media interest in presidential elections, greater spending on presidential elections, and the perception of the greater importance of presidential elections

The student response earn four of the following points:

  • 1 point for each of two reasons identified.

  • 1 point each for explaining why these two reasons could plausibly account for differences in voter turnout in presidential and mid­term elections.

Some acceptable reasons include greater information available about presidential candidates and issues, greater media interest in presidential elections, greater spending on presidential elections, and the perception of the greater importance of presidential elections
